introduction: Susan B. Anthony was a pioneering women's rights activist who dedicated her life to securing voting rights for women. In November 1872, she was arrested in Rochester, New York for voting illegally in the presidential election. At her trial in June 1873, Anthony delivered this remarkable speech before a hostile all-male courtroom, defending her actions as constitutionally protected rights. She was fined $100—a sum she famously refused to pay. Her case became a watershed moment in the suffrage movement, demonstrating that women were willing to face legal consequences to challenge their disenfranchisement. The speech also served as a public pamphlet distributed across New York State to build popular support. Anthony's legal argument was as technically rigorous as it was politically bold, forcing her opponents to either deny that women were 'persons' under the law or concede that the Constitution required women's suffrage. This tension made the speech both a courtroom defense and one of the most effective pieces of suffragist advocacy of the nineteenth century.
analysis: Anthony's speech exemplifies the Rational Advocate framework through its tight, legally disciplined argument structure. The 'Clear Position Statement' is bold and precise: 'I stand before you tonight under indictment for the alleged crime of having voted...I not only committed no crime but, instead, simply exercised my citizen's rights, guaranteed to me and all United States citizens by the National Constitution.' She immediately identifies the problem and asserts her solution in the same sentence. The 'Evidence Presentation' moves methodically through the constitutional text, quoting the Preamble to establish that 'we, the people'—not 'we, the white male citizens' or 'we, the male citizens'—formed the Union: 'It was we, the whole people...women as well as men.' She then applies the Fourteenth Amendment to demonstrate that state sex restrictions constitute unlawful abridgment of citizen privileges. The 'Opposition Rebuttal' reduces the counter-argument to an absurdity through her famous rhetorical question: 'Are women persons?' She exposes the logical collapse: if women are persons, they are citizens; if citizens, they cannot be denied the ballot. The 'Logical Conclusion' is inescapable—'every discrimination against women in the constitutions and laws of the several states is today null and void.' Students should note how Anthony's numbered, sequential reasoning transforms a political grievance into a legal proof, demonstrating the Rational Advocate's power when deployed with rigorous precision.
